ygData.subject: Re: Looking for a few good men (and women)
ygData.msgSnippet: In a message dated 7/12/99 11:12:11 PM Eastern Daylight Time, seorin@execpc.com writes:
ygData.messageBody:
In a message dated 7/12/99 11:12:11 PM Eastern Daylight Time,
seorin@... writes:

<< 1 - NEVER buy any CD for more than 10 cents. They're just shiny pieces of
plastic
that only cost 10 cents to produce. Since you don't pay for any overhead and
are
simply sticking to cost, this is the most you should ever let yourself pay
for a
CD of any kind.

I see your not paying attention. when you buy a CD your not just buying the
"shiny piece of plastic. you are paying for what is one it, you are paying
for someone to put it on there as well. You are not paying for someone to
check each one to make sure it was done right as it was supposed to have been
done right in the first place.

2 - Never ever rent anything or visit a video arcade You aren't actually
buying
anything, and therefore aren't aquiring these precious materials that are all
anybody ever charges for. If you don't get materials, they don't lose
materials,
so they should charge nothing because they are losing nothing. If you pay
more
than nothing, you are again violating your own principles.

I don't rent =) and why go to an arcade? I have a computer to play games on.

3 - Don't buy gas for your car. Don't even buy a car! The gas for your car is
sold in bulk, and therefore at discount. When you buy gas from a gas
station, it
has gone through several middlemen who add a little to the price each time.
Since
you could buy petroleum from the middle east and process it yourself for no
more
than cost, you shouldn't pay the price a gas station will charge because it
has
been marked up several times. Same goes for cars. No car company that I know
of
mines the metal it needs and then shapes it into the parts needed for the
car.
This again means middlemen and markups, so if you want a car, you need to go
mine
all the materials yourself, process even more petroleum into the plastics
needed,
build your own engine and any other moving parts, and put it all together
yourself. This way you make sure to not pay anything more than cost of
materials.

again, your just looking at the materials, you pay for materials and the work
it takes to make it into what you want. You are not paying for someone to
check and recheck that work, etc.

4 - Refuse paychecks from your place of employment. The only things ever
paid for
are material costs, time and work aren't included.

5 - If you ever get into a legal battle, don't hire an attorney. The paper
they
used on your case does not cost what they charge you. Since they are charging
more than cost, you must refuse to pay them and therefore boycott their
services.
You can represent yourself for cost.

again and again <sighs> materials+the accual work that it takes, not all the
etra work that doesnt' NEED to be done.

Yes, I know this is all rather ridiculous, but that's what things would be
like
if you really followed your ideas here. It's almost as bad as saying 'don't
use
plastic, they charge too much!'. Well... where would you be without plastic?
Think along those lines... where would you be without business? If everybody
charged for cost and nothing more, employees wouldn't get paid and all
businesses
would eventually collapse because any failures they made over the years
would add
up. Since they only charge what it costs them, they don't make any money in
their
business so everything comes from their pockets. Since other businesses can't
afford to pay employees, there is nowhere else to work to gain any money.
Timber!! There goes business as we know it.

Seriously, reconsider what you're saying here. It makes absolutely no sense.
We
all know EQ isn't a real economy (it's downright terrible). Actually, it's
weaker
than a real economy. You see what charging for cost does to a real economy,
can
you imagine what it would do to EQ's? It would be nearly irreversible. I
can't
begin to explain the damages your ideas will cause if they are practiced by
all.
-Rennin of E'Ci
Trade Council GM >>

first learn what I am saying then try and make comments. Your only taking
half of what I said. perhaps you should go back and reread it.
